June 24, 2012: Fiction
KISS THE DEAD, by Laurell K. Hamilton. (Berkley, $27.95.) Investigating a
teenager’s abduction, Anita Blake, vampire hunter, encounters a group of recently
turned vampires.
GONE GIRL, by Gillian Flynn. (Crown, $25.) A woman disappears on the day of her
fifth anniversary; is her husband a killer?
CALICO JOE, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $24.95.) A pitcher beans a promising
rookie, ending both their careers; years later, the pitcher’s son brings them together.
THE STORM, by Clive Cussler and Graham Brown. (Putnam, $27.95.) In the 10th
NUMA Files novel, Kurt Austin and his team battle a plan to change the world’s
weather.
SPRING FEVER, by Mary Kay Andrews. (St. Martin’s, $25.99.) Annajane Hudgens
must decide whether she wants to reunite with her ex-husband.
11TH HOUR, by James Patterson and Maxine Paetro. (Little, Brown, $27.99.)
Detective Lindsay Boxer and the Women’s Murder Club investigate a possible serial
killer.
STOLEN PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $27.95.) When a Minnesota family is
murdered, the Minneapolis investigator Lucas Davenport believes a Mexican drug
gang is involved.
THE INNOCENT, by David Baldacci. (Grand Central, $27.99.) A hit man who has
become a target of the government rescues a teenage girl whose parents have
been murdered.
A DANCE WITH DRAGONS, by George R. R. Martin. (Bantam, $35.) After a
colossal battle, the Seven Kingdoms face new threats; Book 5 of "A Song of Ice and
Fire."
DEADLOCKED, by Charlaine Harris. (Ace, $27.95.) The telepathic waitress Sookie
Stackhouse investigates a murder that has more to do with her than she imagines.
BRING UP THE BODIES, by Hilary Mantel. (John Macrae/Holt, $28.) In this sequel
to “Wolf Hall,” Thomas Cromwell conspires against Anne Boleyn.
THE BOURNE IMPERATIVE, by Eric Van Lustbader. (Grand Central, $27.99.)
Robert Ludlum’s character Jason Bourne must discover the identity of an amnesiac
being chased by the Mossad.
A BLAZE OF GLORY, by Jeff Shaara. (Ballantine, $28.) A re-creation of the Battle of
Shiloh in 1862.
THE WIND THROUGH THE KEYHOLE, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $27.) A new
Non-Fiction
THE AMATEUR, by Edward Klein. (Regnery, $27.95.) A journalist argues that
President Obama is callow and unable to lead.
THE GREAT DESTROYER, by David Limbaugh. (Regnery, $29.95.) The talk
show host’s brother, a lawyer and columnist, describes the president's "war on the
Republic."
WILD, by Cheryl Strayed. (Knopf, $25.95.) A woman's account of a life-changing
1,100-mile hike along the Pacific Crest Trail.
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House, $27.) An Olympic runner's
story of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
IT WORKED FOR ME, by Colin Powell with Tony Koltz. (Harper/HarperCollins,
$27.99.) Rules for effective leadership from the four-star general and former
secretary of state.
KILLING LINCOLN, by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard. (Holt, $28.) The host of
"The O'Reilly Factor" recounts the events surrounding the assassination of
Abraham Lincoln.
EAT AND RUN, by Scott Jurek with Steve Friedman. (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt,
$26.) An ultramarathon champion describes his career and his vegan diet, and
offers motivation and advice to runners.
THE PASSAGE OF POWER, by Robert A. Caro. (Knopf, $35.) From 1958 through
the Kennedy assassination; the fourth volume of “The Years of Lyndon Johnson.”
CRONKITE, by Douglas Brinkley. (Harper/HarperCollins, $34.99.) A biography of
the newsman and longtime anchor of the “CBS Evening News.”
I HATE EVERYONE . . . STARTING WITH ME, by Joan Rivers. (Berkley, $25.95.)
The comedian’s humorous reflections.
STEVE JOBS, by Walter Isaacson. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) A biography of the
recently deceased entrepreneur.
IMAGINE, by Jonah Lehrer. (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $26.) An account of the
science of creativity argues that it is not a gift but a thought process that can be
learned.
WINNER TAKE ALL, by Dambisa Moyo. (Basic Books, $26.) An economist
considers the global implications of China's quest for metal and minerals, timber
and food.
THE POWER OF HABIT, by Charles Duhigg. (Random House, $28.) A Times
reporter’s account of the science behind how we form, and break, habits.
